entry.content:
We are building an API portal on SAP Integration Suite exposing api's from SAP Commerce Cloud for a large global client.

entry.title: Assessing the number of messages in SAP integration Suite
entry.content:
Most of the developers overlook that the billing of iflows is based on the number of messages rather than the iflow design object or number of Users. 

While designing an iflow a judicious choice of Multicast has to be taken into account. 

The moment the multicast is used, it will split a message into a copy of a message and increase the count of messages created in the iflow. 

Also. While creating a solution for successfactors, one optimization can be using AEM brokered rather than point to point SF querying interfaces.

entry.title: Client-Side Pagination in SAP CPI for Synchronous APIs ‚Äì Universal Reusable Groovy Script
entry.content:
Introduction

There are many integration scenarios where a consumer system does not require the complete dataset in a single response, but instead expects only a specific page of filtered data per request. Most available documentation focuses on server-side pagination, where the backend system handles paging. However, in many real-world projects, the backend sends the entire dataset, and SAP CPI is responsible for filtering, sorting, and returning paginated data back to the requester.

In this blog, I will explain:

  • What pagination means in SAP CPI context

  • When to use it

  • Server-Side vs Client-Side Pagination

  • A real synchronous business requirement

  • A universal reusable Groovy script

  • Best practices

    This solution is designed so that any CPI developer can reuse and adapt it easily.

    Business Requirement

    A third-party application invokes an HTTPS API in SAP CPI and passes filtering and pagination requirements in the request body:

     

     
    { "customerCode": "0010000099",
    "companyCode": "", 
    "country": "US", 
    "startDate": "20241027", 
    "endDate": "20251027", 
    "pageNumber": 1, 
    "pageSize": 15, 
    "materialCode": "9999",
    "search": "", 
    "status": "PAID" }

    Process Flow

    1Ô∏è‚É£ Third-party system sends request containing pageNumber, pageSize, search & status
    2Ô∏è‚É£ CPI calls SAP backend and retrieves the complete dataset
    3Ô∏è‚É£ CPI performs:

    • filtering

    • searching

    • sorting

    • pagination

      4Ô∏è‚É£ CPI returns only the requested page in JSON
      5Ô∏è‚É£ The call remains fully synchronous

      üìå Important: Backend does NOT paginate
      üìå CPI is responsible for pagination logic

      Server-Side vs Client-Side Pagination in CPI

      Server-Side Pagination

      In this case, the backend system controls page logic. CPI simply forwards pagination parameters and consumes the already paginated results.

      Example:

       
      GET /api/data?page=2&size=100

      or

       
      $skip=100&$top=50

      This is common when CPI consumes APIs that already support pagination.

      Client-Side Pagination (THIS SCENARIO)

      In this approach:

      • Backend returns complete dataset

      • CPI applies pagination logic

      • CPI returns only the requested page back to the consumer

        This is useful when:
        ‚úî Backend does not support pagination
        ‚úî Business requires rich filtering & search logic
        ‚úî Pagination is UI-driven
        ‚úî Consumer expects metadata like:

        • hasNext

        • hasPrevious

        • totalRecords

          High-Level Solution Design

           

          1Ô∏è‚É£ Third party sends request ‚Üí includes pageNumber, pageSize, search, status
          2Ô∏è‚É£ CPI sends a synchronous request to SAP backend
          3Ô∏è‚É£ SAP returns XML dataset
          4Ô∏è‚É£ Groovy script in CPI handles:

          • XML parsing

          • Filtering logic

          • Searching logic

          • Sorting

          • Pagination

          • JSON structuring

          • Error handling

            5Ô∏è‚É£ Paginated response returned back to consumer

            Universal Reusable Groovy Script

            Designed to be:
            ‚úî Clean
            ‚úî Generic
            ‚úî No internal naming
            ‚úî Easily adaptable
            ‚úî User friendly

            #The Script#

            import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message
            import groovy.json.JsonOutput
            import groovy.util.XmlParser

            def Message processData(Message message) {

            def props = message.getProperties()
            def log = messageLogFactory.getMessageLog(message)

            // Log Properties for Debugging
            if (log) {
            props.each { k, v ->
            log.addAttachmentAsString("Property ‚Äì ${k}", v?.toString(), "text/plain")
            }
            }

            /*********************************
            * INPUT PARAMETERS
            * These can be externalized in iFlow
            *********************************/
            def pageNumber = props["pageNumber"]?.toString()?.isInteger() ? props["pageNumber"].toInteger() : 1
            def pageSize = props["pageSize"]?.toString()?.isInteger() ? props["pageSize"].toInteger() : 10

            // Optional Filters
            def statusFilter = props["status"]?.toString()?.trim()
            def searchFilter = props["search"]?.toString()?.toLowerCase()?.trim()

            // OPTIONAL configurable XML Node Name (Universal)
            // If not provided, script will try auto-detection
            def responseRootNodeName = props["responseRootNodeName"] ?: ""


            /*********************************
            * VALIDATE PAGINATION INPUT
            *********************************/
            if (pageNumber < 1)
            return buildError(message, 400, "Invalid pageNumber", "pageNumber must be >= 1")

            if (pageSize < 1)
            return buildError(message, 400, "Invalid pageSize", "pageSize must be >= 1")


            /*********************************
            * READ & PARSE BACKEND RESPONSE
            *********************************/
            def soap = message.getBody(String)

            if (!soap || soap.trim().isEmpty())
            return buildError(message, 404, "No Data", "Backend response is empty")

            def parser = new XmlParser(false, false)
            def root

            try {
            root = parser.parseText(soap)
            } catch (Exception ex) {
            return buildError(message, 500, "Parse Error", "Unable to parse backend XML response")
            }


            /*********************************
            * IDENTIFY RESPONSE NODE
            *********************************/
            def responseNode

            if (responseRootNodeName) {
            // If user has provided root node name
            responseNode = root.depthFirst().find {
            it.name().toString().endsWith(responseRootNodeName)
            }
            } else {
            // Auto-detection fallback
            responseNode = root.depthFirst().find { node ->
            node.children().any {
            it.name().toString().toLowerCase().contains("record")
            }
            }

            What This Script Does

            This script:

            • Detects or accepts configurable XML root node

            • Converts XML ‚Üí collection

            • Applies filters

            • Applies sorting

            • Slices records using pageNumber & pageSize

            • Generates structured JSON response like: 

               
              { 
              "statusMessage":"Success",
               "statusCode":200, 
              "totalRecordCount":240, 
              "hasNext":true, 
              "hasPrevious":false, 
              "Records":[...] 
              }

              How to Use in IFlow

              1Ô∏è‚É£ HTTPS Sender
              2Ô∏è‚É£ Content Modifier ‚Üí externalize:

              • pageNumber

              • pageSize

              • status

              • search

                3Ô∏è‚É£ Request Reply ‚Üí SAP Backend
                4Ô∏è‚É£ Groovy Script ‚Üí pagination, filtering & JSON creation
                5Ô∏è‚É£ JSON Response returned to requester

                 

                Key Benefits

                 

                ‚úî Caller controls pagination
                ‚úî Reduced payload size
                ‚úî Better performance & UX for consuming applications
                ‚úî Avoids timeout issues
                ‚úî Easy to enhance & maintain

                Best Practices

                ‚úî Validate paging parameters
                ‚úî Always sort before pagination
                ‚úî Return metadata (total pages, hasNext etc.)
                ‚úî Handle empty & boundary conditions
                ‚úî Avoid unnecessary looping
                ‚úî Keep response structure consistent

                Conclusion

                Client-Side Pagination in SAP CPI is extremely powerful when backend systems do not return paginated data or when business needs CPI to enrich filtering and paging dynamically. This reusable script and approach:

                ‚úî simplifies design
                ‚úî supports UI driven API consumption
                ‚úî improves performance
                ‚úî prevents heavy payload handling

                I hope this helps integration teams confidently implement pagination in synchronous CPI scenarios.

                Feel free to share your feedback, thoughts, or questions in the comments.
                Happy Integrating! üòä
